column3: I want to give my side of the story, McMichael said, telling the court that he wants to explain what happened from his point of view. He is one of three defendants in the trial.

column1: Day 2 of jury deliberation in the Rittenhouse trial ends again without a verdict
column3: Jurors spent 46 minutes reviewing two crucial videos — an FBI surveillance recording and footage shot from a drone. Rittenhouse's lawyers called again for a mistrial, this time over the drone video.

column1: Travis McMichael says in his murder trial that he felt threatened by Ahmaud Arbery
column3: I want to give my side of the story, McMichael testified, saying the defendants chased Arbery because there had been break-ins in the area and at one point Arbery grabbed McMichael's shotgun.

column1: The Biden administration sold oil and gas leases days after the climate summit
column3: The Biden administration oversaw one of the largest oil and gas lease sales in American history just days after pledging to take action on climate change at the international climate summit.

column1: Rapper Young Dolph is shot and killed in Memphis
column3: Police say officers responded to a shooting at a cookie shop at around 12:30 p.m. where Dolph, was pronounced dead at the scene.

column1: Deere & Co. workers approve the latest contract offer and will end their strike
column3: The United Auto Workers union says 61% of the members approved the deal on their third vote, even though this offer was strikingly similar to one that 55% of workers rejected two weeks ago.

column1: Jason Mott and Tiya Miles win National Book Awards
column3: Mott's Hell of a Book, about an author's book and his haunted past and present, won for fiction. Miles' All That She Carried: The Journey of Ashley's Sack, a Black Family Keepsake won for nonfiction.

column1: How you can see the nearly total lunar eclipse Friday morning
column3: It will be the second and final eclipse of the year. West Coast night owls and East Coast early risers could catch the peak of the cosmic event.

column1: Aurora, Colo., will pay a $15 million settlement over the death of Elijah McClain
column3: The 23-year-old Black massage therapist died days after an encounter with police in August 2019.

column1: Biden restarts trilateral summit, focused on North American partnership
column3: The meeting with the leaders of Canada and Mexico was the first North American summit of its kind since 2016.

column1: Black pastors gather in Brunswick, Ga., to support Ahmaud Arbery's family
column3: Faith leaders from around the country gathered outside the Glynn County Courthouse in defiance of a defense attorney's efforts to keep Black pastors away from the trial.

column1: 3rd day of jury deliberations ends without a verdict in Kyle Rittenhouse trial
column3: The jury has now deliberated for about 23 hours, including nearly an hour spent reviewing versions of two key videos that captured Rittenhouse's first deadly encounter that night.

column1: Facebook will examine whether it treats Black users differently
column3: Black users, and even some of the company's own employees, have accused the social media giant of racial bias for years.

column1: The winners of the Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards will brighten your day
column3: Among this year's winners are a trio of gossipy raccoons, a joyful bird reunion and an all-powerful prairie dog.

column1: Ann Arbor, Mich., will require all public restrooms to carry menstrual products
column3: Some U.S. states and cities make menstrual products available for free at certain locations, but the Michigan city says it's the first jurisdiction to require them in all public restrooms.

column1: Poetry inspired by a viral photo of drowned migrants wins the National Book Award
column3: Photos of a father and his young daughter, drowned in the Rio Grande, underlined the deadly risks of the immigration crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border. Martín Espada drew on them for his book Floaters.

column1: States are investigating how Instagram recruits and affects children
column3: A bipartisan group of state attorneys general accuses the company of prioritizing its own growth while failing to protect kids and teens, and even manipulating them to keep them on the app longer.

column1: 2 suspected Iranian hackers are charged with trying to intimidate U.S. voters
column3: The two Iranian nationals allegedly sent threatening emails to American voters and spread disinformation ahead of the 2020 election.

column1: He was the top U.N. official in Gaza. An Israeli TV interview cost him his post
column3: The U.N.'s Matthias Schmale reflects on his time as a leading international aid rep in Gaza. He departed UNRWA this week after offending Palestinians with his remarks on Israeli airstrikes.

column1: Tennessee governor invites unvaccinated out-of-state cops to join its highway patrol
column3: In a video, Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee invited police officers from New York to Los Angeles to join the Tennessee Highway Patrol, saying that we won't get between you and your doctor.

column1: 'Twilight of Democracy' author says the autocrats are winning
column3: Historian and Atlantic journalist Anne Applebaum says authoritarian rulers have joined together, creating a network of economic and political support, while suppressing the spread of democracy.

column1: Comedian Vir Das called out sexual violence in India. Now he faces lawsuits
column3: In his Kennedy Center show, Das spoke of two sides of his native India: rich and poor, united but divided over women's rights and more. It was a hit in D.C., but brought legal trouble in India.

column1: Coronavirus FAQ: What is long COVID? And what is my risk of getting it?
column3: One of the surprising aspects of the pandemic is that symptoms can linger months after infection. This syndrome has been called long COVID, and it's had a profound impact on many people's lives.
